results.title: Have a healthy baby: pregnancy. - Rev. ed. (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jane Treiman, Spencer Peel and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: Follows the process of pregnancy, explaining how a baby develops, what a mother experiences, and what prenatal care is necessary to ensure a healthy baby. Animation details the important stages of growth of the human embryo from conception through pregnancy. Stresses the complexity of the process and the role nutrition, exercise and good health habits play.

results.title: Haunting of Barney Palmer (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Barney Palmer was eight years old when his haunting began. Whispers in the waves, images in the mirror, voices in his dreams. Is it the ghost of his great Uncle Barnaby or is it the ghost of somebody not yet dead? Someone, somewhere in this world or in the next has promised to carry him away. For Barney, the answer lies close within the strength of his home.

results.title: Hatred
results.creator_credit: Mitzi Goldman, Rosemary Blight, Australian Film Commission and R B Films
results.brief_description: ‘Hatred’ documents various type of hatred and their consequences, beginning with the hatred that led to the filmmaker’s father fleeing the Holocaust. This in turn leads to an exploration of hatred in the lives of the poor and the coloured in New York, and then to the complex clash of identity, religion, history and emotions between the Israelis and the Palestinians. This is a personal journey that asks bigger social questions about identity and prejudice in the modern world. It is a challenge for anyone willing to broach the issue of the origins of hatred in contemporary society. Director Mitzi Goldman presents herself with this very challenge by confronting hatred head on in an attempt to reach enlightenment. A study guide accompanies the video.

results.title: Hated: G.G. Allin & the murder junkies (D)
results.creator_credit: Todd Phillips and A Skinny nervous guy production
results.brief_description: Todd Phillips uncompromising documentary chronicles the extreme life, music and tragic death of cult hardcore rocker G.G. Allin. Along with his back up band the Murder junkies, Allin wrote and performed nihilistic anthems such as “Bite it you scum”, “I wanna kill you” and “Fuck authority”. Filmed during one of the bands notorious tours, Phillips unflinchingly captures Allin’s violent, self destructive stage performances which involve among other things, self mutilation, public masturbation and defecation on stage. Featured also are Allin’s die hard fans who at times go to disturbing lengths to please their number one rock hero, all the while egging Allin on to fulfil his death wish of suiciding on stage. Allin’s anti-social behavior aside, “Hated” ultimately offers a radically alternative version of the sanitized fantasy of the rock n roll rebel, instead presenting a tragic loner on the outer margins of popular culture.

results.title: Hate = La Haine
results.creator_credit: Christophe Rossignon, Gilles Sacuto, Mathieu Kassovitz, Productions Lazennec, Sept Cinema and Studio Canal Plus
results.brief_description: A critical and box-office success, this powerful film won the Best Director’s Prize at Cannes in 1995 and sent shockwaves throughout the French media on its release. An angry indictment of life on a Parisian housing estate, ‘La Haine’ is packed with sharp street-humour, intense action and propelled by brutally brilliant camera work. The film follows one crucial day in the lives of three ethnically diverse teenagers. With violent showdowns between the police and young people a regular occurrence in the Paris ghettos, the film even attracted the attention of the French Prime Minister who organised a special screening of it for his cabinet. In French with English subtitles. Cast includes Vincent Cassel, Hubert Kounde, Said Taghmaoui and Francois Levantal.

results.title: Has the feature started? = Le Film est deja commence?
results.brief_description: Preceded by “Film annonce”, a 3 minute trailer directed by French writer/artist Maurice Lemaitre in 1993, “Le Film est deja commence?” is an experimental hand-colored/b&w film made in 1951 by Lemaitre which has since influenced both New Wave and avant-garde filmmakers with its combination of aesthetics and politics. The complete film session, made up of a montage of film excerpts and abstract images with dialogue spoken in French, had its World Premiere on December 7, 1951 at the Cine Club of the Latin Quarter in Paris. Contains silent footage with mainly French and some English subtext. Also includes booklet with English translation of the soundtrack.

results.title: Has beans
results.creator_credit: Andrew Tamandl, Miriam Stein and AFTRS
results.brief_description: The world is full of war and where can we hope to escape it? Home? - Certainly not by a stretch of this little computer animation. A lone kidney bean is being given the rough treatment by two much larger, bullying lima beans. In a number of fancy manoeuvres the kidney bean tricks the bullying two into believing they’ve killed him. When the kidney bean reaches his kin a battle of revenge is planned. The plan is foiled once ensconced in battle by the true ruler - he/she who cooks beans in the kitchen. The battle scenes are stylistically similar to and remniscent of the battle scenes in the paintings of Australian artist, John Bracks, where he used pencils and decks of cards symbolically and as structural elements to recreate battle scenes. No dialogue, sound effects only.

results.title: Has anybody here seen Canada?
results.creator_credit: John Kramer, Arthur Hammond, Kirwan Cox, Michael McKennirey, ONF | NFB and Donald Brittain
results.brief_description: Through rare film footage and interviews with some of the pioneers who made film history, this documentary traces the history of filmmaking in Canada from 1939-1953. It covers the establishment of the National Film Board in 1939; the war years; Canada’s first Oscar; and John Grierson’s sudden demise as Canada’s driving force in the industry. We witness the struggles of the private film producers, the development of the film industry in Quebec, and the emergence of the documentary. Above all, the film asks whether the alternating fortunes of the Canadian film industry, in the face of an overwhelming American presence, reflect the attitudes of the Canadian people towards themselves and their culture. Written by Donald Brittain and John Kramer.

results.title: Harvie Krumpet [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Adam Elliot, Melanie Coombs, Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria, Melodrama Pictures and SBS Independent
results.brief_description: Adam Elliot’s bittersweet claymation short work opens in Poland in 1922 with the birth of Harvek Milos Krumpetzki - an innocent child beguiled with the world, born to doting and quite dotty parents. Despite being mercilessly teased as a child, Harvek maintains interest in his surrounds, encouraged by his mother who assists him in collecting wonderful ‘fakts’ about the world. One night Harvek’s life is irrevocably altered when WW2 breaks out and he migrates to a faraway land - Australia. In an attempt to assimilate Harvek changes his name to Harvie Krumpet and, in the suburb of Spotswood, begins a new life involving marriage, parenthood and finally, old age. With its melancholic, absurdist tone, “Harvie Krumpet” ably captures the peculiarities of this fringe-dwelling character whose desire for knowledge and love transcends the many trials and mixed fortunes of his life. Winner of an Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film, and narrated by Geoffrey Rush. Also available on DVD [318606].

results.title: Harvey
results.creator_credit: Peter McDonald, Priscilla Collins, Rachel Roberts and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A dark tale of obsession and loneliness about a grotesque man searching literally and metaphorically for his other half. Through the violent coalescence of his neighbour he achieves his goal, but her resistance forces him to face the painful, irresolvable nature of his obsession with completeness. Cast includes Nicholas Hope and Lisa Angove. Written by Peter McDonald, photography by Murray Lui.
